title: Ataxia Evaluation
icd10: G11.3 (Cerebellar ataxia with defective DNA repair)
G31.89 (Other specified degenerative diseases of nervous system — cerebellar degeneration NOS)
G32.81 (Cerebellar ataxia in diseases classified elsewhere)
G13.1 (Other systemic atrophy primarily affecting central nervous system in neoplastic disease — paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration)
scope: ** Evaluation and management of ataxia in adults. Covers the differential diagnosis approach to cerebellar vs. sensory ataxia, acute/subacute etiologies (stroke, toxic, infectious, paraneoplastic, autoimmune), and chronic/progressive etiologies (hereditary, degenerative, immune-mediated). Includes diagnostic workup, etiology-directed treatment, symptomatic management, and rehabilitation. Excludes isolated vertigo (see Vertigo/Dizziness Evaluation), ataxia in children, and ataxia secondary to acute intoxication without persistent deficits.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Infection screen (cerebellitis, abscess); anemia (B12 deficiency); malignancy (paraneoplastic)
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; leukocytosis suggests infection; macrocytic anemia suggests B12/folate deficiency

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Electrolyte derangements (hyponatremia, uremia); hepatic encephalopathy; renal dysfunction affecting drug clearance
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; hyponatremia <130 mEq/L can cause neurologic symptoms; elevated ammonia/LFTs suggest hepatic cause

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Hypoglycemia can mimic acute cerebellar dysfunction; diabetes as comorbidity in neuropathic ataxia
Hypothyroidism can cause cerebellar ataxia (rare but treatable); thyroid dysfunction in autoimmune conditions
B12 deficiency causes subacute combined degeneration with sensory ataxia; posterior column disease
Essential/Core Labs.target: >300 pg/mL; low or borderline → methylmalonic acid and homocysteine

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Folate deficiency can contribute to neuropathy and myelopathy causing sensory ataxia
Vitamin E deficiency causes spinocerebellar syndrome mimicking Friedreich ataxia; fat malabsorption states
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal (5.5-17 mg/L); deficiency → supplement and evaluate malabsorption

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Hypomagnesemia can contribute to ataxia and tremor; often low in alcoholism
Inflammatory markers for autoimmune, infectious, or paraneoplastic etiologies
Drug toxicity is common reversible cause of cerebellar ataxia; phenytoin toxicity is classic cause
Essential/Core Labs.target: Phenytoin 10-20 mcg/mL; lithium 0.6-1.2 mEq/L; carbamazepine 4-12 mcg/mL; supratherapeutic levels → dose adjust or discontinue

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Acute alcohol intoxication; chronic alcoholic cerebellar degeneration
Essential/Core Labs.target: Negative or low; elevated → address intoxication

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Toxic exposures; illicit substances causing ataxia

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Autoimmune cerebellar ataxia; stiff-person spectrum; high titers (>2000 IU/mL) associated with cerebellar ataxia
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Negative; positive at high titers → autoimmune cerebellar ataxia

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Gluten ataxia is most common autoimmune cause of sporadic ataxia; may occur without GI symptoms
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Negative; positive → trial gluten-free diet; tissue transglutaminase (tTG) for celiac confirmation

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Celiac disease confirmation when anti-gliadin positive; gluten ataxia
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Negative; positive → confirm with duodenal biopsy; strict gluten-free diet

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration (PCD); anti-Yo (ovarian, breast), anti-Hu (small cell lung), anti-Tr/DNER (Hodgkin lymphoma), anti-mGluR1, anti-CV2/CRMP5
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Negative; positive → CT chest/abdomen/pelvis and PET-CT for occult malignancy

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Confirms functional B12 deficiency when B12 borderline (200-400 pg/mL)
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Normal (<0.4 mcmol/L); elevated → B12 deficiency confirmed

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Elevated in B12 and folate deficiency; vascular risk factor
Systemic autoimmune conditions causing CNS involvement (SLE cerebritis, Sjogren syndrome)
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Negative; positive → further autoimmune workup (dsDNA, SSA/SSB, complement)

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Wilson disease (onset typically <50 years); copper deficiency from zinc excess or malabsorption can cause ataxia
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Ceruloplasmin >20 mg/dL; low ceruloplasmin + low serum copper → Wilson disease; low copper → copper deficiency myelopathy

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Wernicke encephalopathy (ataxia, ophthalmoplegia, confusion); alcoholism, malnutrition
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Normal (70-180 nmol/L); low → IV thiamine replacement urgently

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Wilson disease confirmation; elevated urinary copper excretion
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: <40 mcg/24h normal; >100 mcg/24h suggestive of Wilson disease

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Vascular risk factors if stroke-related cerebellar infarction
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: LDL <70 (high risk); assess global vascular risk

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Diabetic neuropathy contributing to sensory ataxia; vascular risk
Neurosyphilis (tabes dorsalis causing sensory ataxia); rare but treatable
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Negative; positive → FTA-ABS confirmation and CSF analysis

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: HIV-associated cerebellar degeneration; opportunistic infections (PML, toxoplasmosis); medication-related
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Negative; positive → CD4 count, viral load, CNS evaluation

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Spinocerebellar ataxia types 1, 2, 3, 6, 7, 8, 10, 12, 17; repeat expansion testing; family history of progressive ataxia
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.target: Negative; positive → specific SCA subtype identified; genetic counseling

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Friedreich ataxia (GAA repeat expansion); onset typically <25 years; cardiomyopathy, scoliosis, diabetes
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.target: Negative; positive (>66 GAA repeats on both alleles) → cardiologic evaluation, diabetes screening

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Ataxia-telangiectasia; childhood onset but mild forms present in adults; telangiectasias, immunodeficiency, cancer predisposition
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.target: Negative; positive → cancer surveillance, immunology referral

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Episodic ataxia type 1 (KCNA1) and type 2 (CACNA1A); recurrent episodes; EA2 responsive to acetazolamide
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.target: Negative; positive → targeted therapy (acetazolamide for EA2)

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Undiagnosed hereditary ataxia after targeted panels negative; novel or rare genetic causes
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.target: Variant of uncertain significance or pathogenic variant identified; many ataxias have no known genetic cause

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Autoimmune cerebellar ataxia; Hodgkin lymphoma association
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.target: Negative; positive → malignancy search and immunotherapy

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Autoimmune encephalitis with ataxia, hyperexcitability, diarrhea
Autoimmune cerebellar ataxia; neuromyotonia; Morvan syndrome
Adrenomyeloneuropathy (X-linked); peroxisomal disorders causing ataxia and myelopathy
Coenzyme Q10 deficiency causes treatable cerebellar ataxia
Refsum disease (phytanic acid oxidase deficiency); ataxia, retinitis pigmentosa, neuropathy
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.target: Normal; elevated → dietary modification (phytanic acid restriction)

Lumbar Puncture.target: 10-20 cm H2O; elevated → obtain imaging before LP; initiate ICP management
WBC <5, RBC 0; pleocytosis → infection or inflammation; lymphocytic → viral, autoimmune, or paraneoplastic
15-45 mg/dL; elevated → infection, inflammation, malignancy; markedly elevated → GBS variant (Miller Fisher)
CSF/serum ratio >0.6; low ratio → bacterial, TB, fungal, or carcinomatous meningitis

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Multiple sclerosis; other inflammatory CNS disease
Lumbar Puncture.target: Absent; present → MS or other inflammatory condition

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Intrathecal anti-GAD production in autoimmune cerebellar ataxia
Lumbar Puncture.target: Negative; positive (especially with high index vs. serum) → autoimmune cerebellar ataxia

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: More sensitive than serum for some paraneoplastic antibodies
Prion disease (Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease) if rapidly progressive ataxia with cognitive decline

Essential/First-line.timing: STAT in acute ataxia for hemorrhage or mass effect; does NOT adequately visualize posterior fossa
Essential/First-line.target: Cerebellar hemorrhage; posterior fossa mass; hydrocephalus; large cerebellar infarction with edema; **NEGATIVE CT does NOT exclude posterior fossa stroke**

Essential/First-line.item: MRI brain with and without contrast (CPT 70553)
Essential/First-line.timing: Gold standard for cerebellar evaluation; assess atrophy pattern, lesions, enhancement; DWI for acute stroke
Essential/First-line.target: Cerebellar atrophy (global vs. vermian vs. hemispheric); acute infarction on DWI; demyelinating lesions (MS); tumor; abscess; enhancement (inflammation, tumor)
Essential/First-line.contraindications: MRI-incompatible implants; severe claustrophobia; GFR <30 for gadolinium

Essential/First-line.item: MRA head and neck (CPT 70544/70547) or CTA head and neck (CPT 70496/70498)
Essential/First-line.timing: If vascular etiology suspected (vertebrobasilar stroke, dissection)
Essential/First-line.target: Vertebral artery dissection or stenosis; basilar artery stenosis or occlusion; posterior circulation aneurysm
Essential/First-line.contraindications: MRA: MRI-incompatible implants, severe claustrophobia, GFR <30 for gadolinium; CTA: contrast allergy, renal impairment

Extended.timing: If sensory ataxia suspected; dorsal column disease; myelopathy; B12 deficiency; copper deficiency
Extended.target: Dorsal column hyperintensity (subacute combined degeneration); compressive myelopathy; demyelinating lesions; syrinx

Extended.timing: Paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration — malignancy search when paraneoplastic antibodies positive
Extended.target: Occult malignancy (lung, ovarian, breast, lymphoma); thymoma

Extended.timing: Occult malignancy search when paraneoplastic antibodies positive and CT negative
Extended.target: Hypermetabolic lesion suggesting occult neoplasm; small cell lung cancer, ovarian cancer, Hodgkin lymphoma

Extended.timing: Sensory ataxia evaluation; peripheral neuropathy; Friedreich ataxia (sensory neuropathy); CIDP; paraneoplastic neuropathy
Extended.target: Sensory neuropathy (reduced SNAP amplitudes); sensory neuronopathy (non-length-dependent); demyelinating neuropathy (CIDP)

Extended.timing: If seizures suspected; progressive myoclonus ataxia syndromes; prion disease (periodic sharp waves)
Extended.target: Normal background; epileptiform discharges; periodic sharp wave complexes (CJD); myoclonic correlates

Rare/Specialized.timing: Evaluate cerebellar metabolites in neurodegenerative ataxia; NAA reduction in neuronal loss
Rare/Specialized.target: Reduced NAA/Cr ratio (neuronal loss); elevated choline (inflammation or tumor); lactate peak (mitochondrial disease)
Rare/Specialized.contraindications: MRI-incompatible implants; severe claustrophobia; GFR <30 for gadolinium

Rare/Specialized.timing: Differentiate MSA-C from cerebellar ataxia without parkinsonism; presynaptic dopaminergic deficit
Rare/Specialized.target: Normal uptake (pure cerebellar) vs. reduced uptake (MSA-C, Parkinson-plus)

Rare/Specialized.timing: Friedreich ataxia — hypertrophic cardiomyopathy screening; cardiac iron deposition
Friedreich ataxia — cardiomyopathy screening; MSA — autonomic cardiac involvement
Rare/Specialized.target: Normal; hypertrophic or dilated cardiomyopathy (Friedreich); LV dysfunction

Rare/Specialized.timing: MSA-C evaluation; autonomic failure (orthostatic hypotension, urinary dysfunction, anhidrosis)
Rare/Specialized.target: Normal; abnormal (cardiovagal, adrenergic, or sudomotor dysfunction) → supports MSA-C diagnosis

Acute/Emergent Treatment.indication: Wernicke encephalopathy (ataxia + ophthalmoplegia + confusion); empiric in alcoholism or malnutrition with acute ataxia

dosing.instructions: 500 mg IV TID for 3 days, then 250 mg IV daily for 5 days; give BEFORE glucose; infuse over 30 min

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Allergic reaction during infusion; clinical improvement (ophthalmoplegia resolves first, then confusion, then ataxia)

Acute/Emergent Treatment.indication: Acute posterior circulation ischemic stroke causing cerebellar infarction within treatment window

dosing.instructions: 0.9 mg/kg IV (max 90 mg); 10% bolus over 1 min, remainder over 60 min; within 4.5 hours of symptom onset

Acute/Emergent Treatment.contraindications: Active hemorrhage; recent surgery; INR >1.7; platelets <100,000; BP >185/110; see full stroke exclusion criteria
Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: BP q15min x 2h, then q30min x 6h, then q1h x 16h; neuro checks q15min during infusion; NIHSS; signs of hemorrhage

Acute/Emergent Treatment.indication: Alternative thrombolytic for acute posterior circulation stroke; single bolus dosing

dosing.instructions: 0.25 mg/kg IV bolus (max 25 mg); single dose; emerging evidence for posterior circulation

Acute/Emergent Treatment.contraindications: Active hemorrhage; recent surgery; INR >1.7; platelets <100,000; BP >185/110; see full stroke exclusion criteria
Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: BP q15min x 2h, then q30min x 6h, then q1h x 16h; neuro checks q15min during infusion; NIHSS; signs of hemorrhage

Acute/Emergent Treatment.indication: Vasogenic edema from cerebellar mass (tumor, abscess); NOT for cytotoxic edema (stroke)

dosing.instructions: 10 mg IV loading dose, then 4 mg IV q6h; for tumor/abscess-related edema only

Acute/Emergent Treatment.contraindications: Active GI bleeding; uncontrolled infection (relative); avoid in stroke
Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Blood glucose q6h; GI prophylaxis (PPI); mood changes; insomnia

Acute/Emergent Treatment.indication: Elevated ICP from posterior fossa mass effect with impending herniation; cerebellar stroke with edema

dosing.instructions: 1 g/kg IV bolus over 15-20 min; then 0.25-0.5 g/kg q6h PRN; target serum osmolality <320

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Serum osmolality q6h (hold if >320); BMP q6h; urine output; neuro exam

Acute/Emergent Treatment.indication: Acute ICP crisis from posterior fossa mass effect when rapid osmotic effect needed

dosing.instructions: 30 mL of 23.4% NaCl IV over 10-15 min via central line; may repeat if needed

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Serum sodium q4-6h (target 145-155); central line required for 23.4%; serum osmolality

Acute/Emergent Treatment.indication: Phenytoin toxicity causing cerebellar ataxia (most common drug-induced cause); supratherapeutic level

doseOptions.orderSentence: Phenytoin dose adjustment or discontinuation N/A IV/PO

dosing.instructions: Hold phenytoin; recheck level in 24-48h; resume at lower dose or switch to alternative AED; chronic toxicity may cause permanent cerebellar damage
dosing.orderSentence: Phenytoin dose adjustment or discontinuation N/A IV/PO

Acute/Emergent Treatment.contraindications: Do not abruptly discontinue if on for seizures — taper and bridge
Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Repeat phenytoin level q12-24h until therapeutic; monitor for seizure breakthrough if reducing dose

Acute/Emergent Treatment.indication: Lithium toxicity causing cerebellar ataxia; supratherapeutic level

doseOptions.orderSentence: Lithium dose adjustment or discontinuation N/A PO

dosing.instructions: Hold lithium; aggressive IV hydration; recheck level q6-12h; hemodialysis if level >4.0 or severe symptoms; resume at lower dose when level therapeutic
dosing.orderSentence: Lithium dose adjustment or discontinuation N/A PO

Acute/Emergent Treatment.contraindications: Psychiatry consult before discontinuation; monitor for rebound mania
Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Lithium level q6-12h; BMP q6-12h; renal function; neurologic exam; hemodialysis if level >4.0

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Episodic ataxia type 2 (EA2, CACNA1A mutation); first-line preventive therapy; reduces frequency and severity of episodes

dosing.instructions: Start 250 mg BID; titrate to 250-500 mg BID-TID based on response; max 1000 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Sulfonamide allergy; severe hepatic or renal impairment; metabolic acidosis; hypokalemia
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: BMP q3 months (metabolic acidosis, hypokalemia); renal function; paresthesias (common, benign); kidney stones (hydration)

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Episodic ataxia type 2; downbeat nystagmus; cerebellar gait ataxia; improves Purkinje cell function

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg BID; may increase to 10 mg BID; 12 hours apart; max 20 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Seizure history (lowers seizure threshold); moderate-severe renal impairment (CrCl <50); concurrent use of other forms of 4-AP
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Seizure risk; renal function at baseline and periodically; GI side effects

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Some spinocerebellar ataxias (SCA); neuroprotective; modest evidence for ataxia improvement in selected patients

dosing.instructions: 50 mg PO BID; take on empty stomach (1 hour before or 2 hours after meals)

Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: LFTs monthly x 3 months, then q3 months for first year, then periodically; neutrophil count; nausea, asthenia

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Cerebellar ataxia (various etiologies); modest evidence for gait improvement; anti-glutamatergic properties

dosing.instructions: Start 100 mg daily; increase to 100 mg BID-TID over 1-2 weeks; max 300 mg/day; avoid afternoon dosing (insomnia)

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Severe renal impairment (dose adjust if CrCl <50); seizure history; livedo reticularis; angle-closure glaucoma
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Renal function; hallucinations (especially elderly); insomnia; livedo reticularis; ankle edema

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Cerebellar ataxia (various etiologies); serotonergic mechanism may improve cerebellar function; modest evidence

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg TID; increase by 5 mg/dose q3-5 days; target 30-60 mg/day divided TID; max 60 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Concurrent MAOIs; severe hepatic or renal impairment
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Dizziness; headache; nausea (usually transient); no dependence risk unlike benzodiazepines

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Neuropathic pain in sensory ataxia; proprioceptive neuropathy symptoms; cerebellar tremor

dosing.instructions: Start 300 mg qHS; titrate by 300 mg q3d; target 900-1800 mg/day divided TID; max 3600 mg/day; adjust for renal function

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Severe renal impairment (dose adjust); respiratory depression with opioids or CNS depressants
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Sedation; dizziness; peripheral edema; renal function; suicidality (rare); respiratory depression if combined with CNS depressants

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Neuropathic pain in sensory ataxia; may help cerebellar tremor

dosing.instructions: Start 75 mg BID; increase to 150 mg BID after 1 week; max 600 mg/day; adjust for renal function

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Severe renal impairment (dose adjust); angioedema history
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Sedation; dizziness; weight gain; peripheral edema; renal function

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Cerebellar tremor; myoclonus in progressive myoclonic ataxia; action tremor refractory to other treatments

dosing.instructions: Start 0.25 mg BID; increase by 0.25 mg q3-5 days; target 0.5-2 mg/day; max 4 mg/day; use lowest effective dose

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Respiratory insufficiency; severe hepatic impairment; acute narrow-angle glaucoma; avoid abrupt discontinuation
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Sedation; respiratory depression; dependence (limit duration); fall risk; cognitive impairment; paradoxical agitation (elderly)

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Cerebellar action tremor (kinetic/intention tremor component); reduces tremor amplitude

dosing.instructions: Start 20 mg BID; titrate by 20 mg/dose q1 week; max 320 mg/day; use LA formulation for once-daily dosing

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Asthma/severe COPD (non-selective beta-blocker); bradycardia (HR <50); AV block (2nd/3rd degree); decompensated heart failure; severe peripheral vascular disease
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Heart rate; blood pressure; blood glucose (masks hypoglycemia in diabetics); fatigue; depression

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Nausea and vomiting associated with acute cerebellar dysfunction and vertigo

dosing.instructions: 4-8 mg IV/PO q8h PRN nausea; max 24 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: QT prolongation; severe hepatic impairment (max 8 mg/day)
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: QTc if risk factors; constipation; headache

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Vestibular symptoms (vertigo, nausea) associated with cerebellar ataxia; short-term use only

dosing.instructions: 25 mg PO q6-8h PRN; short-term use only (48-72h); do NOT use chronically — delays vestibular compensation

Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Sedation; anticholinergic effects; discontinue within 72 hours; does not treat underlying cause

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Fatigue associated with chronic cerebellar disease; daytime somnolence from medications or disease

dosing.instructions: Start 100 mg each morning; may increase to 200 mg daily; take before noon to avoid insomnia

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Severe hepatic impairment; history of left ventricular hypertrophy; arrhythmia
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Blood pressure; heart rate; insomnia; headache; may reduce efficacy of hormonal contraceptives

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Depression and anxiety commonly comorbid with chronic ataxia; does not worsen ataxia

dosing.instructions: Start 25 mg daily; increase by 25 mg q1-2 weeks; target 50-150 mg daily; max 200 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Suicidality (especially first 4 weeks); serotonin syndrome; GI upset; sexual dysfunction; hyponatremia (elderly)

Second-line/Refractory (Etiology-Specifi.indication: Autoimmune cerebellar ataxia (anti-GAD, paraneoplastic); MS cerebellar relapse; acute inflammatory cerebellitis

dosing.instructions: 1000 mg IV daily for 3-5 days; infuse over 1 hour; may follow with oral prednisone taper

Second-line/Refractory (Etiology-Specifi.contraindications: Active infection; uncontrolled diabetes; GI bleeding; psychosis
Second-line/Refractory (Etiology-Specifi.monitoring: Blood glucose q6h; blood pressure; mood/sleep; GI prophylaxis (PPI); potassium

Second-line/Refractory (Etiology-Specifi.indication: Autoimmune cerebellar ataxia (anti-GAD); paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration; Miller Fisher syndrome (GBS variant with ataxia); post-infectious cerebellitis

dosing.instructions: 0.4 g/kg/day IV for 5 days (total 2 g/kg); infuse slowly — start 0.5 mL/kg/h, increase to max 4 mL/kg/h; premedicate with acetaminophen and diphenhydramine

Second-line/Refractory (Etiology-Specifi.contraindications: IgA deficiency (anaphylaxis risk — check IgA level); severe renal impairment; hypercoagulable state
Second-line/Refractory (Etiology-Specifi.monitoring: Renal function (BMP before and after); headache (aseptic meningitis); thrombotic events; infusion reactions; vital signs during infusion

Second-line/Refractory (Etiology-Specifi.indication: Autoimmune cerebellar ataxia refractory to steroids/IVIG; Miller Fisher syndrome; paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration (limited benefit once neuronal loss established)

dosing.instructions: 5-7 exchanges over 10-14 days; 1-1.5 plasma volumes per exchange; albumin replacement

Second-line/Refractory (Etiology-Specifi.contraindications: Hemodynamic instability; active infection; severe coagulopathy
Second-line/Refractory (Etiology-Specifi.monitoring: Electrolytes (calcium, magnesium) q exchange; fibrinogen; blood pressure; line complications; infection

Second-line/Refractory (Etiology-Specifi.indication: Refractory autoimmune cerebellar ataxia (anti-GAD, other antibody-mediated); gluten ataxia not responding to diet; MS cerebellar involvement

dosing.instructions: 1000 mg IV on day 0 and day 14; repeat q6 months based on response or CD19/CD20 counts; premedicate with methylprednisolone, acetaminophen, diphenhydramine

Second-line/Refractory (Etiology-Specifi.contraindications: Active hepatitis B (check HBsAg, anti-HBc before); active severe infection; severe heart failure
Second-line/Refractory (Etiology-Specifi.monitoring: CBC with differential q3 months; immunoglobulin levels q6 months; hepatitis B reactivation screening; PML risk (rare); infusion reactions

Second-line/Refractory (Etiology-Specifi.indication: Steroid-sparing agent for chronic autoimmune cerebellar ataxia; maintenance immunosuppression

dosing.instructions: Start 500 mg BID; increase to 1000 mg BID after 2 weeks; max 3000 mg/day (rarely needed)

Second-line/Refractory (Etiology-Specifi.contraindications: Pregnancy (Category D — teratogenic); active infection; hypersensitivity
Second-line/Refractory (Etiology-Specifi.monitoring: CBC q2 weeks x 3 months, then monthly; LFTs monthly; renal function; GI symptoms (diarrhea, nausea); infections; live vaccines contraindicated

Second-line/Refractory (Etiology-Specifi.indication: Alternative steroid-sparing agent for autoimmune cerebellar ataxia; TPMT testing required

dosing.instructions: Check TPMT before starting; start 50 mg daily; increase by 25 mg q2 weeks to target 2-2.5 mg/kg/day based on TPMT activity

Second-line/Refractory (Etiology-Specifi.contraindications: TPMT deficiency (severe myelosuppression); concurrent allopurinol (reduce dose by 75%); pregnancy
Second-line/Refractory (Etiology-Specifi.monitoring: CBC weekly x 4 weeks, then q2 weeks x 3 months, then monthly; LFTs monthly; TPMT genotype/phenotype before starting; infections; lymphoma risk (long-term)

Second-line/Refractory (Etiology-Specifi.indication: Gluten ataxia (positive anti-gliadin antibodies); strict adherence required for benefit; improvement may take 6-12 months

dosing.instructions: Complete elimination of wheat, barley, rye, and cross-contaminated oats; dietitian referral essential; compliance monitoring with repeat anti-gliadin antibodies

Second-line/Refractory (Etiology-Specifi.monitoring: Anti-gliadin antibody levels q6 months (should decrease with compliance); clinical ataxia scores (SARA, ICARS); nutritional status; B12 and iron

Second-line/Refractory (Etiology-Specifi.indication: CoQ10 deficiency (primary cerebellar ataxia responsive to supplementation); may benefit some mitochondrial ataxias

dosing.instructions: Start 300 mg BID; increase to 600 mg BID if tolerated and deficiency confirmed; take with fatty meal for absorption; may take months for improvement

Second-line/Refractory (Etiology-Specifi.monitoring: Clinical ataxia scores; CoQ10 levels if available; GI tolerance; well-tolerated

Second-line/Refractory (Etiology-Specifi.indication: B12 deficiency causing sensory ataxia (subacute combined degeneration); posterior column disease

dosing.instructions: 1000 mcg IM daily x 7 days, then weekly x 4 weeks, then monthly indefinitely; or high-dose oral 1000-2000 mcg daily if absorption adequate

Second-line/Refractory (Etiology-Specifi.monitoring: B12 level at 2 months; MMA for adequacy of replacement; neurologic exam; CBC (reticulocyte response); sensory exam improvement may take months

Second-line/Refractory (Etiology-Specifi.indication: Vitamin E deficiency ataxia (abetalipoproteinemia, fat malabsorption); treatable cause

dosing.instructions: 800-1200 IU daily; higher doses may be needed in malabsorption syndromes; take with fatty meal

Second-line/Refractory (Etiology-Specifi.contraindications: Caution with anticoagulants (may increase bleeding risk at high doses)
Second-line/Refractory (Etiology-Specifi.monitoring: Vitamin E levels q3 months initially; PT/INR if on anticoagulants; clinical ataxia assessment

Second-line/Refractory (Etiology-Specifi.indication: Copper deficiency myelopathy and ataxia (zinc excess, bariatric surgery, malabsorption)

dosing.instructions: Acute: 2 mg IV daily x 5 days; Maintenance: 2 mg PO daily; remove cause (e.g., stop excess zinc)

Second-line/Refractory (Etiology-Specifi.contraindications: Wilson disease (must be excluded before copper supplementation)
Second-line/Refractory (Etiology-Specifi.monitoring: Serum copper and ceruloplasmin q3 months; zinc levels; CBC (copper deficiency causes anemia, neutropenia); neurologic exam

Second-line/Refractory (Etiology-Specifi.indication: Friedreich ataxia — may reduce cardiac hypertrophy; limited evidence for neurological benefit; investigational

dosing.instructions: 5 mg/kg TID (typically 150-300 mg TID); take with food; not FDA-approved but used off-label

Second-line/Refractory (Etiology-Specifi.monitoring: Cardiac function (echocardiogram); LFTs; clinical ataxia scores; well-tolerated

Second-line/Refractory (Etiology-Specifi.indication: Friedreich ataxia — FDA-approved Nrf2 activator; first approved therapy for Friedreich ataxia (2023)

dosing.instructions: 150 mg PO once daily on empty stomach (1 hour before first meal); swallow capsule whole

Second-line/Refractory (Etiology-Specifi.contraindications: Moderate-to-severe hepatic impairment; avoid strong CYP3A4 inhibitors; concurrent hepatotoxic drugs
Second-line/Refractory (Etiology-Specifi.monitoring: LFTs at baseline, monthly x 3 months, then q3 months; BNP (cardiac); weight; clinical ataxia scores (mFARS)

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology consultation for ataxia evaluation, localization (cerebellar vs. sensory), and diagnostic workup guidance
Movement disorders specialist referral for chronic or progressive ataxia requiring specialized evaluation and genetic testing interpretation
Stroke neurology consultation if acute cerebellar stroke suspected based on sudden onset, vascular risk factors, or central exam findings
Physical therapy for gait training, balance exercises, fall prevention, and adaptive strategies for progressive ataxia
Occupational therapy for fine motor training, adaptive equipment (weighted utensils, writing aids), and ADL modifications
Speech therapy for cerebellar dysarthria (scanning speech) evaluation and treatment; swallow evaluation if dysphagia present
Genetic counseling referral when hereditary ataxia (SCA, Friedreich, EA) is confirmed or suspected based on family history or genetic testing results
Cardiology referral for Friedreich ataxia (cardiomyopathy screening) or MSA-C (autonomic cardiovascular dysfunction)
Neurosurgery consultation for posterior fossa mass lesion, large cerebellar stroke with mass effect, or obstructive hydrocephalus requiring intervention
Oncology referral for paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration with identified or suspected malignancy
Psychiatry referral for depression or anxiety management in chronic progressive ataxia affecting quality of life
Dietitian referral for gluten-free diet implementation in gluten ataxia; nutritional assessment in malabsorption-related ataxia
Social work for disability resources, adaptive equipment funding, home safety assessment, and caregiver support in progressive ataxia
Palliative care referral for advanced degenerative ataxia (MSA-C, advanced SCA) for symptom management and goals of care discussion

Patient Instructions.item: Return immediately for sudden worsening of ataxia, new headache, vomiting, or change in consciousness (may indicate stroke or mass lesion requiring emergency treatment)
Return immediately for new double vision, slurred speech, weakness, or numbness (may indicate brainstem or cerebellar stroke)
Do not drive until cleared by neurology due to impaired coordination and fall risk affecting vehicle control
Use assistive devices (walker, cane) as recommended by physical therapy to prevent falls and injury
Remove tripping hazards at home (rugs, clutter, poor lighting) and install grab bars in bathroom to reduce fall risk
Do not stop or adjust seizure medications (phenytoin, carbamazepine) without physician guidance as this may cause breakthrough seizures
Avoid alcohol as it worsens cerebellar function and may cause permanent cerebellar damage with chronic use
For gluten ataxia: strictly avoid all wheat, barley, rye, and cross-contaminated products; improvement may take 6-12 months of strict adherence
Keep a symptom diary tracking episode frequency, duration, and triggers for episodic ataxia to guide treatment optimization
Genetic testing results may have implications for family members; discuss with genetic counselor before sharing results

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Alcohol cessation to prevent further cerebellar damage and reduce ongoing cerebellar toxicity (alcohol-related cerebellar degeneration primarily affects anterior vermis)
Smoking cessation to reduce vascular risk factors for posterior circulation stroke and overall health improvement
Regular exercise program adapted to balance limitations (swimming, stationary bike, seated exercises) to maintain strength and cardiovascular health
Fall prevention strategies: adequate lighting, non-skid footwear, remove loose rugs, install handrails on both sides of stairs
Strict glycemic control (HbA1c <7%) if diabetic neuropathy contributing to sensory ataxia component
Mediterranean diet for vascular risk reduction in stroke-related ataxia; adequate nutrition in malabsorption-related ataxia
Vitamin B12 and folate-rich diet (meat, fish, dairy, leafy greens) to support nerve health and prevent deficiency-related ataxia
Weight management to reduce joint stress and improve mobility in patients with gait ataxia
Stress management and adequate sleep (7-9 hours) as stress and fatigue may worsen ataxia symptoms and trigger episodic ataxia attacks
Medic alert bracelet recommended for patients with episodic ataxia (may appear intoxicated during episodes) or Friedreich ataxia (cardiac risk)

differential.features: Posterior fossa stroke (cerebellar infarct/hemorrhage), drug toxicity (phenytoin, lithium, alcohol), Wernicke encephalopathy, post-infectious cerebellitis, acute MS relapse, basilar migraine
differential.tests: Sudden onset; vascular risk factors (stroke); medication history (toxic); triad of ataxia/ophthalmoplegia/confusion (Wernicke); recent viral illness (post-infectious); prior MS or demyelinating events

differential.features: Paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration, autoimmune (anti-GAD), gluten ataxia, vitamin deficiency (B12, E, thiamine), prion disease (CJD), CNS lymphoma, brain abscess
differential.tests: Progressive over weeks; weight loss/smoking (paraneoplastic); GI symptoms (gluten/celiac); dietary history (B12/E); rapid cognitive decline (CJD); fever/immunosuppression (abscess)

differential.features: Hereditary (SCA types, Friedreich, EA, AT), degenerative (MSA-C), alcoholic cerebellar degeneration, chronic drug exposure, idiopathic late-onset cerebellar ataxia
differential.tests: Family history (hereditary); progressive over years; autonomic failure (MSA-C); heavy alcohol use history; chronic medication exposure; anterior vermis atrophy on MRI (alcohol)

differential.features: Episodic ataxia type 1 (EA1), episodic ataxia type 2 (EA2), vestibular migraine, TIA (vertebrobasilar), metabolic decompensation
differential.tests: Attacks lasting minutes (EA1) or hours (EA2); myokymia between attacks (EA1); nystagmus between attacks (EA2); migraine features; vascular risk factors (TIA)

disposition.criteria: Clear etiology identified (drug toxicity with drug held, BPPV treated, B12 initiated); stable neurologic exam; safe ambulation (with or without assistive device); able to tolerate oral medications; outpatient follow-up arranged with neurology; no red flags for central cause

New subacute ataxia requiring expedited workup (paraneoplastic panel, autoimmune labs, MRI with contrast); acute ataxia with diagnostic uncertainty; intractable nausea/vomiting requiring IV fluids and antiemetics; initiation of IV immunotherapy (steroids, IVIG); unsafe ambulation with high fall risk and inadequate home support

Acute posterior fossa stroke (cerebellar infarction or hemorrhage); posterior fossa mass with mass effect or hydrocephalus; Wernicke encephalopathy with altered consciousness; basilar artery occlusion; need for emergent neurosurgical intervention (posterior fossa decompression, EVD)

Posterior fossa stroke or mass requiring neurosurgical capability not available at current facility; need for endovascular intervention (basilar artery thrombectomy); need for specialized neurocritical care

Neurology follow-up in 2-4 weeks for chronic ataxia evaluation results; movement disorders follow-up in 4-8 weeks for genetic testing results; PCP within 1-2 weeks for medication adjustment; PT/OT within 1 week for ongoing rehabilitation
